turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Next case for argument is Number 726, Mitchell against Donovan.
You may proceed whenever you're ready, Mr. Castner.
Mr. Castner.

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.

The appellants in this case are the Communist Party of the United States of America, Communist Party of the State of Minnesota, Mrs. Charlene Mitchell and Mr. Michael Zagerell, 1968 Communist Party Presidential and Vice Presidential candidates, Mrs. Betty Smith State Secretary of the Minnesota Communist Party, 10 presidential electors from the State of Minnesota for the Communist Party, two plaintiff appellees representing the 2,394 registered voters who signed a petition to put the Communist Party candidates on the 1968 ballot and one registered voter who did not sign the petition.
The Communist Party of the State of Minnesota as well as the National Party are unincorporated associations.
The Communist Party of Minnesota held a duly convened statewide convention in Minnesota on or about June 23, 1968.
They elected six delegates and an alternate delegate to the National Convention of the Communist Party U.S.A, which was called for and held in New York, July 4 to July 7, 1968.

At the Communist Party of Minnesota Convention, a motion was passed that if the Communist Party U.S.A nominated a presidential ticket that the Communist Party of Minnesota would endeavor to place on the ballot in Minnesota those candidates.
Mrs. Betty Smith attended that convention as a delegate in New York.

Mrs. Mitchell and Mr. Zagerell were duly nominated by that convention immediately following the Communist Party of Minnesota mounted a campaign to obtain the requisite number of signatures, under Minnesota Law, 2000 to place the candidates on the ballot.

On this nominating petition appeared the name of the ten Communist presidential electors and under Minnesota Law on the ballot only appears the name of the candidates and by Minnesota Law, a vote for the candidates is a vote for those electors.
On Sunday, September 8, the party completed its campaign to collect signatures.

On the next day, Monday the 9th, representatives of the Communist Party, the National Office as well as the State appeared at the Office of Secretary of State of Minnesota Joseph Donovan to file the nominating petition.
The party representatives arrived at the Secretary of State's Office during the noon hour.
Immediately after noon, they tendered their petition.
This petition was anticipated and they were presented a written refusal of the Secretary of State.
He did examine the contents of the package and satisfied himself that it was the nominating petition for the Communist Party.
His refusal said, “Please be advised that upon the advice of the Attorney General of Minnesota and at his direction as a matter of law, I hereby officially refuse.”

The Attorney General had issued an opinion which was also a copy of which was given to the representatives, in which the Attorney General said, “In view of the Federal Statutes and quoted in full Sections 841 and 842 of the Communist Control Act, we are of the opinion that you should refuse to accept for filing the nominating petition in question.
However, any doubts relative to this matter can only be finally resolved by the Courts pursuant to appropriate legal proceedings.”
The party went to Court.
Judge Devitt convened the three-fudge District Court and on September 30th, heard arguments of counsel.
Following that and inspite of a request for a permanent injunction, the Court ruled that a hurried decision would not be appropriate.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What did you ask for?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: In the prayer for relief, we ask both for a temporary and permanent injunction.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Against what?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: Against the state officials requiring them to place the party candidates on the ballot.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: When?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: In the June '68 Election.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is that the only injunction you asked for?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: That is the only injunction at that time.

We ask for such other and further relief in the prayer for relief and following the issuance of the temporary injunction and the passage of election, we noticed it for trial came back to Court and found ourselves arguing a motion to dismiss as moot.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And then what?
Did you amend your -- did you amend your complaint?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: I'm sorry?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Did you amend your complaint?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: Yes, we amended our complaint and the three-judge court granted the motion to amend the complaint.
In the prayer, we said that the Communist Party of Minnesota intended to participate in future local, state and national elections.
This amendment was granted and it was supported by an affidavit of Mrs. Smith to this effect on behalf of the party.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well in the prayer, you amended the complaint to allege that the Communist Party of the State intended and hoped to participate in future elections that I assume was not in the prayer

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: How if at all was the prayer amended?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: The prayer was not amended.
We felt that under Rule 54(c) the request for additional relief would incorporate our desire to obtain a permanent injunction.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The only injunction you ask for, as I understand it explicitly, was an injunction to an election that is now passed and an election in which your clients were placed on a ballot in that time.

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And that thereafter the only explicit relief demanded either in the original complaint or in the complaint that's amended was one for declaratory relief, is that right?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: That is correct, although we feel we were not able to come back to Court because of the disposition of the motion of the state to dismiss as moot to ask for a permanent injunction which we feel we are entitled to by this party.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, yes, you were entitled to ask for it and then the dismissal would have been a denial of it but you did not in fact ask for it, did you?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: No, we did not.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: An injunction is strong medicine and generally the rules of pleading required that if you want an injunction you have to ask for an injunction and then it is not incorporated in the ordinary boilerplate language of such other further relief that maybe appropriate in circumstances etcetera, etcetera.

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: We did see --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You know that is on my mind I suppose to these questions and that is whether or not this Court has jurisdiction under Title 28 of the Code Section 1253 whether or not in other words there was here a denial of an injunction and there was a denial of an injunction only if you asked for an injunction that was denied?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: We feel that the relief asked for, we did ask for a permanent injunction.
We feel that this is similar to the Moore v. Ogilvie case the specific injunction to put them on the ballot was not necessary after the election.
All that remained was declaratory relief which if granted would have the effect of an injunction.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What necessitated three-judge court?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: We sought to enjoin the both by the temporary relief requested the permanent injunction and the declaratory relief to stop to enjoin the execution and enforcement of the Communist Control Act of 1954.
Had we obtained the declaratory relief we asked for, it would have had the effect of restraining the operation and enforcement of the Act.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I don't see any request for an injunction for restraining and enforcing of the Communist Control Act.

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: The United States is not a party.
We could not restrain the United States from enforcing the Act as against State Elections because the United States has no power to interfere with the state elections in this regard.
The only state -- the only Government officials who have the power to execute and enforce the Communist Control Act in elections are the state officials.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You did not -- even not ask them a Court injunction against --

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: Well, we asked for the relief which the Court held below entitled us to a three-judge court, to restrain the state officials from preventing the Communist Party from being on the ‘68 ballot.
Following that election, we amended our compliant to let the Court know that the Communist Party intended to participate in future elections.

The next point is that in support of the lower court's order dismissing the complaint as moot, we believe that it is clear that the Communist Party will continue to participate in elections both on a statewide level and on a national level.

The party has participated in the past in 163 elections, 41 states have been the site of those elections and in Minnesota there have been 27 elections all but one of these have been election contests for state or national office.

Now, the Attorney General has made the argument below that it is and this was adopted by the three-judge court that it is just speculative that the party will run for future elections and he said the earliest time that could come up again is 1972.
We would like to point out to the Court that the time is upon us now for the party to participate in other elections.

We have statewide elections, we have elections for United States Senator as well as for the House of Representatives and if this case is -- if the order of the court below is upheld as moot, the Communist Party will have participated in litigation for almost two years and be in precisely the situation that we argue such an order would place us that is that we would have to go back into Court again and litigate the question of the right of the party to appear on the ballot.
The court below refused to reach the merits saying that a hurried decision would not be wise or would be unwise.
They also wish the United States to be a party.
Chief Judge Devitt teletyped the United States Attorney, Mr. Ramsey Clark and ordered him to appear on the Court.
Mr. Clark replied with a letter saying that he had other commitments and did not appear.

However, he sent the United States Attorney for the District of Minnesota to appear amicus curiae and he did appear and argued to the Court that the Communist Control Act does not bar the party from the ballot that it can be interpreted citing Catherwood as for the proposition that Communist Party, pardon me, candidates could run as long as they didn't use the label Communist Party.

He also suggested to the Attorney General that Minnesota Law might allow the Communist Party to appear on the ballot with the designation Communist Party, an argument which was not accepted by either the Court or by the Attorney General.
I think that that position of the United States fails because it does not recognize that the party itself under Minnesota Law has a right.

There are provisions in the law, which allow a party to present candidates if it receives a percentage of votes and we feel that a vote for party enthronement is equally as important as a vote for party candidates.
The United States in its brief relied on Salwen and Rees.
The only other case construing the Communist Control Act in terms of elections for the proposition that a Communist Party candidate could run for election.

In that case the New Jersey Courts as well including the Supreme Court did not accept even that argument and said that it would be a keen way to avoid the effect of the Act if Communist Party Candidates could run and hide from the public or not mention the fact that they are espousing Communist Party principles.

So, both the appellants and the appellees in this case agree that there is no question that the Communist Party -- I'm sorry that the Communist Control Act bars the Communist Party or its candidate from running in elections whether or not they disclose or speak to the effect that they are running under the Communist Party label.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you want us to declare that Act unconstitutional?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: We also -- yes, we also want a permanent injunction.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And we are to declare that statute unconstitutional without the United States Government having anything to do with it?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: We believe the United States Government has had a clear position over the years.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What position, who is now speaking for the United States Government?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: The United States has not appeared on this case.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How can we declare an Act of Congress unconstitutional without the Attorney General of the United States or somebody representing him being here?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: It's my understanding that the Court did not request the appearance of the United States.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You mean it's the Government?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: Yes.
Judge Devitt --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: He gave the statutory notice to the Attorney General, didn't I?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: Not only gave statutory notice but teletyped an order requiring him to appear.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: True.

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: The response to which was the appearance of the U.S. Attorney as amicus curiae.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, as I understand the judgment of the lower court was that there was no case in controversy because the Attorney General in his amicus brief had suggested that the law did not apply to Minnesota.
Is that what Judge Devitt said?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: That is one of the points relied upon.

The judge pointed out three reasons why the cases was or why the motion was granted to dismiss that it was moot, that it was not right for adjudication and that there was not an actual case of controversy as required by the declaratory judge would say.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It wasn't moot, was it?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: We do not --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: If it wasn't moot why did you amend?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: Well, we did not anticipate --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You amended because it had been moot up till that time.
There is nothing wrong with that, it's done everyday.

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: We amended because the Court granted the relief of the party to appear on that ballot.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That is right.
Now, you don't know what the next Secretary of State would do about this Act, do you?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: We believe we do.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How do you --

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: The Attorney General.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Who is the next Secretary of State?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: The next Secretary of State will be elected in the coming elections?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How do you know what he's going to do when you don't even know who he is?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: But we feel Mr. Justice that this case is going to be presented again before that man leaves office.
The filing date for the national elections are in July of 1970.
His office does not expire until November of 1970.
The Attorney General will be in office until November of 1970.
The party is now seriously considering the state and national elections in Minnesota.
I believe no candidates have filed although a number are talking of their intent to do so.

If this case is dismissed, if the order dismissing the case is moot as upheld, the appellants are precisely in the position they were in the summer of 1968 of having to come back to Court again with exactly the same defendants and waste the resources on their time again covering the same ground.
Moreover, we take the position that the mere change of the constitutional officers of the state is not enough to moot the case.
There is no authority for the proposition save the one amicus curiae brief of the United States Attorney.
There is no legal authority for the proposition that the act does not apply.
I can't imagine that a constitutional officer would take another position.

They cite the opinion of a Connecticut Attorney General ruling the same way Salwen and Rees stands for not only that proposition but to the Communist party candidate without his party cannot participate in elections and the United States failure to appear.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: We are speaking about lack of case and controversy, I mean what Connecticut does in somebody else that's not before us.
Do you have anything to argue for other than a declaratory judgment?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: Yes, we believe we are entitled to a permanent injunction.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What authority do you have for that?
You originally asked to get on the ballot of 1968 and then the Court allowed you to amend and then you came in and said you proposed to it to those candidates the future.
Is there anything in the record that says that the state intends to prevent you from doing it?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: No, and the state can continually present us with the same situation.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is there anything in the record that says the State intends to?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: There is.
In the transcript of the hearing on September 30th, the Court asked Mr. Kyle who at that time was Solicitor General, it is on page 18 of the appellants brief.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Appellants brief.

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: And in the appendix -- on page 69 of the appendix.
The Court inquired of counsel.
On another subject I noticed that counsel's affidavit says on information and belief.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Just a deferment, Mr. Castner.
Do we -- we're sure we have your place page 69 of the appendix, is that correct?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: Yes, that is correct.
I misspoke.
It was at the hearing on November 25th, ‘68 hearing arguments on the motion to dismiss as moot and on the appellant's motion to amend.
This exchange took place.

On another subject, I noticed that counsel's affidavit says on information and belief, he has learned that you or the Attorney General are going to persist in your viewpoint that if some other communist affiliated people file, you are going to take the same position.
Is there any basis for this information and belief?
Mr. Kyle replied, “I think there probably is.
At least there is no new case law which has come down which would as far as I am concerned dictate a different result ultimately.”

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And who's Mr. Kyle?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: Mr. Kyle was the Solicitor General in the case and he is appearing for appellees today.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The representative of the Attorney General?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: He was the -- the Chief Officer Solicitor General of the State of Minnesota.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Oh, he is a subordinate of the Attorney General, was he not at that time?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And he is no longer assistant?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: No, he is not.
Yes, he is, I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: He's present in the courtroom but in the office, is that what you mean?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: Well, I misspoke I -- he did leave the office of Solicitor General who I understand that came back to it and is presently serving that institution now.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I don't suppose anybody to repudiate the fact that he was representing the Attorney General, right?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: Well, they were -- in their brief subsequent, they did not like the effect of this admission in Court and argued in opposing the noting of probably jurisdiction that also tying to the argument that this would not be presented again until 1972 that there would be another constitutional officer, pardon me, and no way for the Court to determine that the same --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: They denied that Kyle was an officer at the time he made the statement.
They repudiated.

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: No, they did not?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: They checked him out?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: They did not.
The United States, we feel, did not appear to defend the Constitutionality of the Act because they have had a long standing provision that such an Act violates the Constitution of the United States.

In 1948, when Congress was considering and the year subsequent a number of bills which would have barred the Communist Party from activity, two congressional subcommittees were holding hearings on legislation aimed at restricting the activities of the Communist Party.
One bill would have banned from the ballot and any election in the United States all political parties directly or indirectly affiliated with the Communist Party of the United States.
After the bills' constitutionality was assailed by a number of witnesses, the committee recessed to await an opinion from the Department of Justice on this subject.

The opinion was forthcoming in a letter on March 9, 1948 to the Chairman of the House Committee on House Administration that letter said and I quote, “Although this department is in complete sympathy of course with the desire that no subversive or disloyal person should be permitted to hold a position of honor, trust, or profit in the Government, it is believed that the bill under consideration will be of doubtful validity and enforceability for many reasons.

The most outstanding of which is that it might be regarded as in the nature of Bill of Attainder, a denial of due process of law and an attempt by the Federal Government to legislate insofar as it would apply to the qualifications of a political party in any election in a field for which no federal authority exists.
The United States has not in any case that we can find moved from this position.
We believe that this position has been consistent regardless of the change of constitutional officers.
We believe also that any state official with the state of the law as it is today would be the same as the Attorney General of Minnesota in this case.

We urge the Court and feel the Court has authority to issue a permanent injunction restraining state officials from preventing Minnesota candidates, from Minnesota Communist Party candidates, from presenting their nominating petitions and participating in elections.
We feel the Court should reach the merits of constitutionality that the argument of the Act does not apply is without merit and is not relied by legislative history.

There was little agreement on the extent of the scope of this Act in the legislative debates as few as they were, but there was agreement on one thing that this Act barred the party from the ballot and the authorities that have studied and written about this Act subsequent to its passage have agreed that the Act has this effect.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Whether this -- whether they denied that the Act applied to you for the Communist Party?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: Pardon me Mr. Justice?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Where did they deny that the Act applied to the Communist Party?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: They being the Department of Justice or the legislative debates.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: People you have to hear if you want to get an injunction?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: Oh, the appellees in case have not denied that the Act applies and let me take this opportunity, thank you for reminding me, there is an error in the appellant's brief on page 45.

On the first paragraph of page 45, the second sentence says, “both the attorney general and the U.S. Attorney argued below that the Communist Control Act infringes upon the power of the states in this regard that is to qualify electors.”
The inclusion of the Minnesota Attorney General should not be there, this was an error.
Turning to the merits, we urge the Court to find the Act unconstitutional as a Bill of Attainder.
We believe the Act is a classical Bill of Attainder and the decisions of this Court and all who sat on this Court considering the cases of attainder would find this Act a classical Bill of Attainder.
First, the Act outlaws the Communist Party by legislative fiat.
The party itself was outlawed in this case in the SACB Case.
I'm sorry, this Court in that case pointed out that if the party by name were outlawed, the Act would be a Bill of Attainder.
The Communist Control Act of 1954 made this finding.
The second test is whether there is a legislative finding of guilt.
In 841 there is the flat conclusion that the Communist Party should be outlawed and in 841 also, in fact an instrumentality of a conspiracy to overthrow the Government of the United States.

There is a legislative finding of guilt taking away from the power of the Court to make determination not granting a hearing to the party on its conclusions and we urge that the position of the appellees that this Court may take into consideration the legislative findings in other and not related acts as to the nature of a Communist Party cannot support this Act.
We feel that's a novel assertion that the findings of one Act can be held to support another.

This Act was adopted on the eve of adjournment in 1954, there were no committee hearings on the Act saved Congressman Dice, the legislative history has been properly described by this Court in the Catherwood case has given little guidance.
The third test, we feel, is met as if the party is punished.

There is no comparable example of such a flat legislative finding of guilt in the absence of a judicial trial and the cases of this Court going back to the post Civil War Bill of Attainder cases Cummings and Garland clearly show that punishment need not be imprisonment but in fact point out specific -- in specific example precisely what has happened under this Act that the party is barred from the ballot.
The fourth test and one which this Court which many authorities feel this Court has set forth in Dallas is also met.
There is no opportunity for the party to reform itself.
It cannot escape the provisions of this Act.

Nothing it does can allow it to come to the ballot and in fact, the interpretations of the Act do not allow an individual candidate supporting the principles of the party to appear without party endorsement.
The second provision and there are many or the second of unconstitutionality and one which we feel is in equal weight is the infringement upon freedom of speech.

This Court in the last term in Williams and Rhodes made it clear with the right vote and First Amendment protects that right both for the right of qualified voters to cast their votes as well as the right of individuals to associate with a party or an association to cast their votes.
The state would urge that the paltry showing of the party in the last election, 415 votes, would minimize the importance of participation in the electoral process.
We feel that cannot be serious in this regard.
The real importance and contribution to participation in the political process is the forum of an electoral contest as freedom of speech.
This Court has made it clear that freedom of speech is on the highest of scale of constitutional liberties and we feel the Court has also made it clear that the right to vote is at the top with it.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You mean that it's argued because there's such a small number of alleged voters on that ticket?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: Well they pointed --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The State has a right to -- state has a right to sue (Inaudible)?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: They argued this in terms of its being moot, that is with such a paltry showing how can we expect that the party would make another serious attempt and have ignored the fact of 163 elections of this party.

They also have pointed to the hiatus of participation in electoral politics by the party from 1950 until the 1968 election and this lack of participation was not due to a lack in interest but to the effect of the McCarran Act.
The party itself has come back into electoral politics in 1968.
They did participate in local elections in New York, Rashid Storey and Jesus Colon ran for mayor and the comptroller.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What actual defense did they put up for that law?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: Pardon what?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What actual defense have they put up for a law of this kind that bars a party from running in the state if it acts within the law?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: On the merits they merely say that to balance the interests of taking the risk that a party if elected would destroy our way of Government.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How many voters did you say they had?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: 415 in Minnesota.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How many -- what's the population of Minnesota?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: I believe it is about 3 Million.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And they were afraid this 450 would overturn them?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: I am afraid they'll have to answer that for themselves.
I will save my remaining time for rebuttal.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But you are going to spend more time on the preliminary question of whether or not the Court has jurisdiction under Section 1253?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: I believe the state will spend quite a bit of time on it and I will respond in rebuttal.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Kyle?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
Maybe I should clarify my position with Attorney General's Office at the outset in response to some questions which arose.

The Solicitor General of the State of Minnesota which is my title is an appointed position by the Attorney General of Minnesota and serves at the pleasure of the Attorney General is the equivalent of an Assistant or Deputy Attorney General.

When this litigation first arose and through the District Court proceedings, I was the Solicitor General of the State of Minnesota and for a period of a approximately six months thereafter, I performed a different function within the Office of the Attorney General with a different title and then returned to position as Solicitor General which I now -- which position I now hold.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Excuse me?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Yes, as of now.
The statement which is found in the record concerning the position of the Attorney General which was referred to by --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The statement what?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: The statement Your Honor which was found in the record concerning the position of the Attorney General with respect to a future election and made by me -- was made by and the statement as such stands now to the extent that the Attorney General will see fit to follow what I or someone else on the staff may tell him to do with respect to a given election.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The Attorney General of your states have elected officers?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: For a what, a four-year term?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Four-year term.
His term expires this year.
He is not a candidate for reelection as is the Secretary of State who's term also expires this year and he is not a candidate for reelection.
So, absent this particular question arising this fall and it could, we are going to have two new and different constitutional officers in office when a similar petition if ever is presented.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You will have new officers after January of 1971?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The Governor and the Attorney General take office in January.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Right, in January, Your Honor.

Now, the position of the state or the position of the Attorney General and the Secretary of State who were named defendants in this action at the very outset was a three-judge district court was not required to hear this action because no request was made that would have the effect of restraining the operation or enforcement of Act of Congress that even if the plaintiffs here secured the declaratory relief which they sought that the party be placed upon the ballot and that their candidates be allowed to run, this would not have the effect of putting and grinding to a halt, so to speak the operations of Communist Control Act 1954 or whatever operation that Act had.
That --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Did the action of the Secretary of State in refusing for nominating petitions purport to be got under a state statute or wasn't that presumably in the federal court?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: It was done -- the legal authority -- there was a dispute on this Your Honor.

He received the nominated petition as the advice of the Attorney General as to what he should do, the Attorney General wrote him a memorandum or opinion whatever you want to call it, pointed out the provisions of the Communist Control Act and Communist Control Act only and said that this Act appeared to apply and therefore barred the party from participation in the election.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It purports to preempt absent Congress was elected except –-

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: No, question about that, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: On the face of the -- of your state statutes would prevent it.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: There would be no disabling state statute.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So this is good.
There will be a state saying the federal law --?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Federal Law requires us to do this, this was --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: These are our state law?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: That is correct.
That is the position we took and it's the position which we upheld throughout.

It was on that basis that we had also objected to the convening of three-judge court because we took the position that we were not acting under the color of state law which was a requirement of Section 1983 The Civil Rights Act.
When a state officer acting under color of state law or the three-judge district court disagreed with us on this proposition and was convened and then made its decision and this appeal followed.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Kyle, I don't --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: May I ask you a question, I want to get it.
They filed a petition against the state officer, didn't they?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: They filed -- no, Your Honor they presented to the Secretary of State --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: -- a nominating petition on behalf of the Communist Party of the United States.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And what did he do?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: He refused to accept it.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: On what grounds?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: That the Attorney General told him to refuse to accept it.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You mean the Attorney General of the state?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Of the State of Minnesota.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And you say he did it on the ground that this federal law barred it?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: On the ground of the Communist Control Act?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That doesn't get your state out, does it, to say that the federal law bars it.
Wasn't it that you did let them know whether they would accept his name as a candidate?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: We said no.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You said, no.
Then you did deny and you have refused to let him get on the ballot.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You did it on the grounds that the Federal Law prohibits it.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What did you tell him about the First Amendment?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: We didn't tell him anything about the First Amendment.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You didn't mention that?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: No, we did not.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you think it had anything to do with it?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: At the time that we were presented with the petition, Your Honor the situation arose in this manner.
The petition is there.
We look at the Communist Control Act on its face, at least in my opinion and I still have this opinion.
It would if Constitution would bar the Communist Party from the electoral process in the State of Minnesota.
Now, the only decision --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That was an issue between you and the people who wanted to get on the ticket.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Between the State of Minnesota, not between the Federal Government but between the State of Minnesota and the people who wanted to get on the ticket list?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Well, I don't -- I don't know where that follows, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well doesn't it, who objected, who denied it except the state.
It doesn't make a new forth ground --

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Well, the state, the state you're right.

It did in a sense that the state said no you are not going on the ballot and then it was an issue as between the state and people presenting the petition to whether they were going to be allowed to go on the ballot.
We physically said, “No.”
And our only --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You did not let him get on?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And let him get on here?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Well, they have not.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Say what?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: They've been not.
They ran in 1968.

Not pursuant to anything we did but pursuant to an order of the three-judge district court but there has been no request since that time to come on again and there had been no opportunity or there has been opportunity in 1969 which we had at least local elections in the State of Minnesota as far as our office was concerned.

We received no information from anyone that this problem had arisen again. Notwithstanding, I might point out, the affidavit presented by the Secretary, Mrs. Smith of the Communist Party that they intended to participate in future Minnesota local elections.
At least one year has gone by and if participation took place it was brought to no ones attention.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Kyle, would it be possible to your mind as Solicitor General to apprise that since the three-judge court has already ruled on the 1968 election that you see no reason why they shouldn't follow that in later elections and let the party on the ballot.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Well, I would have no difficulty with it except that the basis of the three-judge court's ruling Your Honor was to specifically reserve the question of the constitutionality of the Act.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And they haven't passed it on yet.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: And they haven't passed it on yet.
They simply -- we were in a time as all of these election cases are --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, my point is that you feel obliged to follow an Act of Congress which has no means of enforcing it you if you don't follow it and you have the opinion of a three-judge constitutionally set up Court that you did not have to follow it.
Isn't that enough for you to say that well let's forget about it?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: I'd like to say yes but I can't Your Honor.
I don't think it is.
If the three-judge court had ruled on the merits of the Act, declared the Act to be unconstitutional --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You have a further impediment, have you not, you are not the Attorney General of Minnesota.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But one of his subordinates who can't give opinion.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Sir, that is pleasure --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, can't we get somebody in that can give us opinion for the State of Minnesota if you are not authorized to do it, why were you sent here for if not to make a statement?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: I think I am authorized, no I'm authorize to make statements on behalf the State of Minnesota.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, you're authorized to make statements in this argument but you're not authorized to give an opinion that hasn't been asked for yet.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: We were asking you for one?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Well, you're asking me to enforce an argument, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: We are asking you on the ground that you are here purporting to be the representative of the Attorney General of the State of Minnesota.
Now, are you and do you have a full authority to represent him in this argument before us?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, I do.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But you have no authority to give an opinion about the ballots in next September's election.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Yes, he has not asked me for my opinion concerning the matter.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you deny having that authority?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: I'm not sure, I understand your question?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you deny having the authority which the Chief Justice asked you about?
If so how can you claim to be the representative of the Attorney General of the State of Minnesota?
We usually have representatives for parties who can give us statements about the position of the party.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: I have given you statements, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But you don't deny them that you have authority to determine for the State of Minnesota, speak for him now and say whether you are opposing this party getting on the ticket?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Yes, I am opposing this party getting ticket.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: I am opposing this party on the ticket this is the position which we took earlier and this position which we have taken this litigation.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You do it on the ground that you -- that the state does it of its own will or because it does it.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: I do it on the ground with an Act of Congress has said as I read that Act of Congress that the party shall not go on the ballot.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And what did the Court tell you?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: The Court put them on ballot because the Court said we do not have enough time to resolve what they consider to be the difficult grave constitutional issues which we presented.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But why should this case not be met on its face?
That litigant should meet cases and say whether or not the State of Minnesota is now opposing this party getting on a ticket.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Well, whether it is going to be met on the merits or not Your Honor is a decision which this Court is going to make right now which I have no control.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You have no control over it but you have control over the safe case?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: But I -- as I read the decisions of this Court.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you say that you have in a less authority than the Attorney General of the State of Minnesota has to state views on this particular case when you are now representing the State of Minnesota.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You do not claim any less authority than the Attorney General.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Now, it is our position on this appeal that jurisdiction is also lacking in addition to the fact that a three-judge court in our view was not required below but that there was no denial of permanent injunction in this litigation and that is a requirement of Section 1253, a section which recently was reviewed in analogous context in a Goldstein decision by this Court about two months ago.
It says that this Court has appellate jurisdiction from a final order granting a permanent injunction in this case.
Now, there was no request for a permanent injunction in this case.
It was requested that the Secretary of State except the nominating petition and that he place those candidates upon the ballot.
Now, to the extent that that request for relief constituted a request for a permanent injunction, it was granted.

The temporary mandatory injunction issued by the three-judge court gave to the plaintiffs, every aspect of the injunctive relief which they had originally sought and it was only at that stage that we probably could have appealed to this Court from the granting of that temporary injunction which we chose not to do.

The amendment which came two weeks later but before the election has two statement of facts allegations that the Communist Party of Minnesota intends to participate, whatever that means, in future local, national, state elections and further that the Attorney General will continue to give his view that the Communist Control Act bars.
No request that any state official present or future be barred from taking any action, none was asked for and therefore none was given.

So, it is only I submit, if this Court reads the order of dismissal as moot, as having the effect of denying their request for permanent injunction that this Court would have jurisdiction and I submit that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What request for a permanent injunction?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Excuse me, I see.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Only if we read the dismissal as denying you say there a request for a permanent injunction for my request.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Only if you read it as having the effect of denying whatever their prayer for relief.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, what was it?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: That the Communist Control Act declared unconsciously.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: For declaratory judgment?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Not for an injunction?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: No, there was no request for an injunction.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's what I thought.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: No request at all.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: On the injunctive request, it was respect to what election.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: All with the respect to the 1968 Election.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What prayer did they grant then on?
What prayer did they grant the injunction on that?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: A motion for a temporary, mandatory --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Where is that in the appendix?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: The motion, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes, where is the request for an injunction that they granted?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It was page 14, on page 14.
Paragraph two.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Paragraph two on page 14, isn't that correct?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And that was granted you did not take an appeal from that.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What is that, would you read that line?
And the first line in paragraph two.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: That the Court issues a temporary restraining order and permanent injunction.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And what does that word permanent injunction mean?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: It means they permanently tell the second.
I think it means with respect of the in context in which it is brought up that the Secretary of State take and put the candidates on the ballot.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: For what?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: For the 1968 election.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What would permanent injunction, request for a permanent injunction mean to you?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: It means that he does it for all time with respect to the 1968 election.
Once the election occurs no -- there is nothing more to occur.
The aforesaid petition --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Where does it say with reference to that particular election?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Well, because it says to accept and file the aforesaid petition and that aforesaid petition only refers to the 1968 election and require the defendant Donovan include upon the ballot for the general election to be held on November 5, 1968.
And they are on the name --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What Section 5 as to where, on the next page, what is usually required in bills for injunction?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: For such further and all relief that the Court may deem equitable and proper.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What do you think about that now?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: I think it is a standard boilerplate phrase, which is put in every -- well, I don't think it has any meaning in of it self.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, but I have used it many times in complaints.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: I don't think it is.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I always thought it meant that you are asking not only for that relief but for any other relief that is necessary to protect the rights they complained of.
Protect the rights, what did you mean anything but that?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: But if it does means that Your Honor, it means that to protect the rights within the context of the this case.
(Voice Overlap) Excuse me.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That is rather technical construction, isn't it?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: I don't think so.
I think yours is a rather liberal construction of the same phrase.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It might be and Court sometimes are liberal in protecting First Amendment rights.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: You mean it's not as quicker this time.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: In any event, Mr. Castner made a statement during his argument to the effect that they could have or couldn't or unable to make an amendment to the complaint which would have amended the prayer for relief.

There is no reason that that amendment could not have been made some time during the course of these proceedings but they chose not to and the motion was then made to dismiss and it was granted by the three-judge court and it is from that order that we are now before this Court.

The propriety of dismissing this lawsuit is perhaps the first and foremost issue before the Court and I respectfully submit that all of the factors taken together that the three-judge district court properly determined that there was no actual controversy between these parties and that this was not a case like the Moore v. Ogelvie decision of this Court within the last year which was capable of repetition and yet evading a review because I think even that --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, we reach that -- we reach even that question.
We don't reach if we don't have a jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: You do not have jurisdiction, Your Honor, that is correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You don't even reach this first question.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: That is correct, that is correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: One of the point of our proceedings according from all 14, there was no pleadings subsequent to that, wasn't it?
This amended complaint.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: No because the -- that's correct, Your Honor.
The amended complaint, the motion to amend was granted on the same day that the motion to dismiss the complaint was granted.
These were -- they're contained in the same order of the three-judge district court.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Are you complaining that we don't have jurisdiction or that the court below didn't have jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Complaining that you do not at this stage have jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Pardon?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Complaining that you do not have jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That we do not.
Why?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Because this Court to have jurisdiction it must be an appeal from a decision of a three-judge -- from an order required to be heard by a three-judge district court.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Did it make an order?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Yes, there was an order?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What was it?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: That the communist candidates be placed upon the ballot but it is our position that if we did not need a three-judge district court below.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Or is that your ground that there should have been one judge instead of a three-judge?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: That's right.
That's one of the grounds and the other --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What is the other ground?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: The other ground is that this is not an appeal from an order granting a permanent injunction.
Those are the two --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Does it -- suppose it denies that?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Excuse me, that's denying a permanent injunction?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And you said, it does not grant?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: I meant, it denied, I stand corrected.
It is though --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Whether it amounts -- it amounts for that almost doesn't it into the dismissing?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: No, I don't think it is does because I don't see how it can amount to anything if there is no request for it, to begin with.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That's going back to another question as well in that request.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Well, but it's --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: From my viewpoint, that depends on paragraph five not on paragraph two?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Well, that -- that could be although I don't think --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Well, Mr. Kyle, assuming that the three-judge court would have turn this on ground that there was no request for an injunction.
As I read the opinion, it has turned on the ground it is no case controversy and you know are urging two grounds that they were right saying there is no case of controversy.
And that we don't even have to reach that because there was no denial of injunction, is that right?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: We don't have the benefit of any view of the three-judge court whether an injunction was requested.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: No, no because they simply viewed the --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: And if we think that it was sufficiently requested that there was a denial here then I take it what we have to decide as whether they were right or wrong in holding that there was no case of controversy within Golden and Zwickler.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Assuming you also conclude that this was a type of case required to be heard by a three-judge court.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And now this amended position of yours, what do you mean -- what do you mean by “there's no case of controversy”?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: I mean that as I read the decisions of this Court that it is required and under the declaratory judgment action that there must be a live controversy between --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And there's not any here?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: I don't think there is, Your Honor, notwithstanding the fact that we are standing before this Court.

I think it is hypothetical at best as to whether these parties are ever going to be locked together on this issue again and I don't think that the pleadings or the past history of the party, the Communist Party, for that matter, support the likelihood of this occurring.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Did they purport to make this a class action in the pleadings, I have not -- (Voice Overlap)?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Yes, they did Your Honor, with respect to class action, with respect to those who signed the nominating petition and those who did not sign the nominating petition.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But as to future candidates and future elections?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: No, there's no reference, see there is no reference any place to future candidates or future elections.
And with respect to the class actions, of course, this Court in Hall v. Beals which was dismissal of a suit in Colorado concerning its residency requirements.

The Colorado legislature, as I recall, amended that requirement during the course of litigation, so that the plaintiffs would qualified and I think -- I believe this Court said that in so doing the class of which the plaintiffs were members when the suite started disappeared because they were no longer eligible and I don't think we really have a class even of the plaintiffs here because these are plaintiffs who signed a nominating petition for the 1968 election or who did not sign the nominating petition for the 1968 election and that election having gone by, their status as class members, I think is very tenuous.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Are you familiar with the case earlier this term of the Court's I think arising out of Ohio in which we dismissed perhaps without much explanation but I wonder if we could indicate.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Brockington v. Rhodes?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: -- and then give some indication that this was a dismissal because there was no indication that these people were going to be candidates in the next election, is that something you have before you?
I just wonder, if you're familiar with that.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Yes, if it's the case that I am thinking it is one in which he did not bring it as class action, it's Brockington v. Rhodes.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Yeah, that's the one I'm thinking.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: In which the Court does --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What's the name of it?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Brockington.
B-R-O-C-K--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Where is that in your brief? Do you know at the moment?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: I'm not sure that it is cited in the brief, Your Honor but it is 90 Supreme Court 206.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What was the volume?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: 90 Supreme Court at page 206.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, in this case, if there is evidence in formal letter that they do intend to keep doing for the Communist Party?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: There is evidence in the form of an affidavit by the Secretary of the Minnesota Communist Party that they intend to participate in future Minnesota local election.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is there anything in the record that contradicts that?

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So, that's not in the writing, which is different from Rhodes case.

turn.speaker: richard_h_kyle
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Kyle
turn.text: Yes sir.
It is for these reasons that we have taken the position Your Honor that the case should be dismissed for lack of jurisdiction in this Court and is failing to present an actual controversy.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you Mr. Kyle.
Mr. Castner you have few minutes left here.
You have about 10 minutes.

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: I would like to speak first of the question of 1253 jurisdiction.
Appellants urge that the Goldstein case is not applicable to this case.
Goldstein said that the only interlocutory orders which the Court has power to review under 1253 are orders granting or denying preliminary injunctions.
We do not ask what the order did not deny a preliminary injunction.
The order of July of the three-judge court in this case was a final order.
We feel this is similar to Moore and a number of other cases where the need for injunctive relief though quite previously asked for has evaporated.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But what's the statute say 28 United States Code Section 1253.

It doesn't tell you, there's no question about that concerning whether it was final or not final, whether it is interlocutory of final where it's concerned of whether or not comes under the terms of that jurisdictional statute.
It appears on page two of appellees' brief.
I think you know what it says.
It is kind of a rhetorical question of mine, that I have it before me and nobody answered.
I did not end it.
I'm sorry but the --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The statute says for granting or denying an injunction, that's what the statute says.

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Interlocutory or permanent.

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: We asked --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What injunction was denied in this case?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: The original injunction that we asked for was a permanent injunction prior to the election.
This injunction was denied by the Court issuing a final order saying the case was moot and that there was not an --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The injunction but rather the injunction you asked for was granted.

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: It was one of three types of injunctions we asked for.
We asked for a temporary restraining which was denied, for a temporary injunction which was granted, and for a permanent injunction which was not granted.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What was the permanent injunction that you asked for and please show it in the record?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: Prior to --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: On page 14 is your injunction.

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: -- of the appendix.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What you asked for in paragraph two.

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: The Court issues a permanent injunction requiring the Defendant Secretary of State Joseph Donovan to accept and file the petition for nomination as required by the statutes and required that Donovan include upon the ballot the names of Mitchell and Zagarell.
The permanent injunction we asked for, we urge is the only relief we could have asked for prior to the election.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Aren't you bound on what you ask for here?
Number one, you asked for a specific people, the Secretary of State and the 1968 election.
Now, you wanted to form an injunction you receive, any Secretary of State in any election, any time in the future.

You didn't ask for anything more than that the Secretary of State by name Joseph L. Donovan, accept this petition and that he'd be permanently enjoined from not accepting it for 1968, isn't that what you asked for?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: That is what we asked for prior to the election.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And you wouldn't deny it.
Now, what did you ask for in injunctive relief after that?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: We did not.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, then how are you here?

turn.speaker: lynn_s_castner
turn.label: Mr. Lynn S. Castner
turn.text: We amended the complaint and we feel that rule 54 is broad enough and clear that for such other and further relief that we are entitled to a permanent injunction.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well then, if you filed a case in which you asked for a two declaratory judgments and for such of them further relief, you think you'd get under this Act?
